review.title: Linguistic Analysis of Requirements of a Space Project and their Conformity with the Recommendations Proposed by a Controlled Natural Language
review.abstract: The long term aim of the project carried out by the French National Space Agency (CNES) is to design a writing guide based on the real and regular writing of requirements. As a first step in the project, this paper proposes a lin-guistic analysis of requirements written in French by CNES engineers. The aim is to determine to what extent they conform to two rules laid down in INCOSE, a recent guide for writing requirements. Although CNES engineers are not obliged to follow any Controlled Natural Language in their writing of requirements, we believe that language regularities are likely to emerge from this task, mainly due to the writers' experience. The issue is approached using natural language processing tools to identify sentences that do not comply with INCOSE rules. We further review these sentences to understand why the recommendations cannot (or should not) always be applied when specifying large-scale projects.

metadata.title: Linguistic Analysis of Requirements of a Space Project and their Conformity with the Recommendations Proposed by a Controlled Natural Language

sections.text: The Space Agency (CNES) is to draft a written guide based on the real and regular writing of requirements. As a first step of the project, this work proposes a linguistic analysis of requirements written by CNES engineers in French. The aim is to determine to what extent they comply with two rules laid down in INCOSE, a current guide to written requirements. Although CNES engineers are not obliged to follow a controlled natural language when formulating requirements, we believe that this task will result in regularities, mainly based on the experience of the authors. The problem will be addressed using natural language processing tools to identify sentences that do not comply with the INCOSE rules. We will continue to review these sentences to understand why the recommendations cannot (or not) always be applied in the specification of large projects. Keywords: Requirements · Specifications · Technical Writing · Corpuslinguistics Controlled Natural Language.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In fact, we are able to determine for ourselves how we should behave.

sections.heading: 2 Methodology
sections.text: There are several written requirements guides, most of which have been designed to avoid undesirable characteristics of natural language ("unrestricted natural language entails a variety of known problems" [16]), such as ambiguity, polysemy, vagueness, etc. [1, 17]. To ensure that these guidelines are close enough to actual practice and therefore truly applicable, we have decided to make a diagnosis of the way the specifications are designed at the CNES and then compare this process with the recommendations of one of these guides. The aim is to assess the conformity of the requirements with the recommendations and see if they can be brought closer to reality. We will first briefly describe our corpus of requirements and the tools we use, and then the linguistic phenomena selected for study in the controlled natural language that we use as a reference.

sections.heading: 2.1 Description of the corpus
sections.text: A subset of the specifications of an Earth observation satellite called the Pleiades, launched in 2011, was given to the CNES. From these specifications, we extracted the requirements, i.e. only those parts that play the role of contractual obligations between the CNES and its subcontractors. Requirements should not contain unnecessary information such as examples or comments. Requirements should be autonomous; they should therefore not be linked to the text segments that precede or follow them. In the specifications given to us, the requirements were easily identifiable because they were framed by certain keywords.The requirements were all written in natural language, but some also included tables or charts (which were removed as they could not be analysed automatically).Theoretically, they should also be fully understandable without these numbers - but in practice this is not always the case.

sections.heading: 2.2 Tools and resources
sections.text: Syntactical analysis was carried out using Talismane [18], an open source parser developed in our laboratory, while the open source corpus processor Unitex [19] was used for sentence chunking. Short handmade Perl scripts were written for other purposes (requirement extraction, long sentence detection, etc.) We also compared our corpus to two other corpus (reduced to exactly the same size): (1) a manual written by CNES experts on techniques and technologies used for the construction and operation of spacecraft intended for half-experts, and (2) some articles in the French daily Le Monde.

sections.heading: 3 First results
sections.text: In subsection 3.1 we present our results regarding the frequency of conjunctions, pronouns and long sentences in our corpus. In subsection 3.2 we propose a selection of examples that break the two rules of INCOSE and try to classify them according to their necessity (mandatory, useful or undesirable).2 "The controller will retrieve the driver for the day," must be withheld from him. "The controller will send the driver his itinary (sic) requirements for the day." Thanks to the syntactical analysis we were able to retrieve all occurrences of the so-called combinators (since no exhaustive list was given), we searched for all coordinating and subordinating conjunctions.

sections.heading: 3.2 Qualitative analysis (analysis of examples)
sections.text: This year, it is closer than ever before in the history of the country.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions and future work
sections.text: We analyzed a corpus made up of real requirements written and used by CNES engineers to design a space system. We showed that their texts, even if they did not explicitly follow guidelines, had some interesting features, such as shorter sentences than in other text genres. We also examined two rules (relating to conjunctions and pronouns) of INCOSE, a guide to writing requirements. Using several examples from our corpus, we looked at cases where these rules were justified and others where they were not applicable (at least when applied verbatim) and should be refined. In fact, we believe that INCOSE, like the underlying guidelines, lacks adequate linguistic foundations and is not close enough to the real practices of engineers. For example, the recommended absence of pronouns from requirements - which sometimes implies cumbersome heavy repetitions - hardly seems to be compatible with its ideal of "precision."
